subject: Re: [junit] Test Results with Exception Handling
msgSnippet: ... It depends what you want to test. For example, the method loader.loadFile(String filename) loads your file. Test 1: test if you can load a valid file:
messageBody:
> Should a test case return a success or failure on a method when it throws an
> exception.


It depends what you want to test.

For example, the method loader.loadFile(String filename) loads your file.

Test 1: test if you can load a valid file:

public void testLoadSuccess() {
try {
loader.loadFile("correctFileName.txt");
} catch (Exception e) {
fail("NO expection should have been thrown");
}
// if you get here, everything was fine and because that's what
// you wanted to test, just do nothing
}

Test 2: test that if you load an file that does not exist, the
FileNotFoundException is thrown:

public void testLoadFNFEThrown() {
try {
loader.loadFile("INcorrectFileName.txt");
// if you arrive there, then your loadFile method does not
// work properly -> simply tell that the test failed.
fail("FNFE should have been thrown");
} catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
// in that case, everything's fine -> just exit the method
// this will count as a success because no AssertionFailedExc.
// has been thrown
return;
} catch (Exception e) {
fail("FNFE should have been thrown and not another exception");
}
}

Repeat the Test 2 for every exception that can be thrown by a method.

You can also re-throw the exception but IMO you loose information (you
don't know why the error appened, just that it happened).

Hope it helps,

-Vladimir
